paragraphs.text:
%md
## Introduction
The Customer 360 sample data is an integrated dataset of 1) accounts and account owners, 2) purchases by the people who own those accounts, and 3) transactions between these accounts. The combined dataset is then used to perform the following common graph query and analyses: pattern matching, detection of cycles, finding important nodes, community detection, and recommendation.

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4862919/63682754-d46f0680-c822-11e9-89ae-9c84e0aec2b3.jpg)

msg.data:
Introduction

The Customer 360 sample data is an integrated dataset of 1) accounts and account owners, 2) purchases by the people who own those accounts, and 3) transactions between these accounts. The combined dataset is then used to perform the following common graph query and analyses: pattern matching, detection of cycles, finding important nodes, community detection, and recommendation.

paragraphs.title: Connect to Graph Server
paragraphs.text:
%pgx
import oracle.pgx.api.*
import oracle.pgx.api.filter.*
import groovy.json.*

baseUrl = 'http://graph-server:7007'
username = 'graph_dev'
password = 'Welcome1'

conn = new URL("$baseUrl/auth/token").openConnection()
conn.setRequestProperty('Content-Type', 'application/json')
token = conn.with {
  doOutput = true
  requestMethod = 'POST'
  outputStream.withWriter { writer ->
    writer << JsonOutput.toJson([username: username, password: password])
  }
  return new JsonSlurper().parseText(content.text).access_token
}

instance = Pgx.getInstance(baseUrl, token)
session = instance.createSession("my-session")
analyst = session.createAnalyst()

paragraphs.title: Get Pre-loaded Graph
paragraphs.text:
%pgx
graph = session.getGraph("Customer 360")

%pgx
// Show all properties about the account "xxx-yyy-201"
graph.queryPgql("""
  SELECT ID(a), a.account_no, a.balance
  FROM MATCH (a)
  WHERE a.type = 'account'
    AND a.account_no = 'xxx-yyy-201'
""");

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: One-hop Relationships from an Account
paragraphs.text:
%pgx
// Show any related information about the account "xxx-yyy-202"
graph.queryPgql("""
  SELECT a.account_no, LABEL(e), n.type
  FROM MATCH (a)-[e]-(n)
  WHERE a.type = 'account'
    AND a.account_no = 'xxx-yyy-202'
  ORDER BY LABEL(e)
""");

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

xxx-yyy-202	purchased	merchant

xxx-yyy-202	transfer	account

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Pattern Matching
Find accounts that had an inbound and an outbound transfer, of over 500, on the same day. The PGQL query for this is:

msg.data:
Pattern Matching

Find accounts that had an inbound and an outbound transfer, of over 500, on the same day. The PGQL query for this is:

paragraphs.text:
%pgx
graph.queryPgql("""
  SELECT a.account_no
       , a.balance
       , t1.amount AS t1_amount
       , t2.amount AS t2_amount
       , t1.date
  FROM MATCH (a) <-[t1:transfer]- (a1)
     , MATCH (a) -[t2:transfer]-> (a2)
  WHERE t1.date = t2.date
    AND t1.amount > 500
    AND t2.amount > 500
    AND a.balance < 300
""");

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

account_no	balance	t1_amount	t2_amount	date
xxx-yyy-202	200	900	850	2018-10-06

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Detect Cycles
Next we use PGQL to find a series of transfers that start and end at the same account such as A to B to A, or A to B to C to A.

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4862919/63682879-1ef08300-c823-11e9-8559-a142851b1ed1.jpg)
![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4862919/63683037-8a3a5500-c823-11e9-9677-c3788f4df1cd.jpg)

msg.data:
Detect Cycles

Next we use PGQL to find a series of transfers that start and end at the same account such as A to B to A, or A to B to C to A.

paragraphs.title: A to B to A
paragraphs.text:
%pgx
graph.queryPgql("""
  SELECT a1.account_no AS a1_account_no, t1.date AS t1_date, t1.amount AS t1_amount
       , a2.account_no AS a2_account_no, t2.date AS t2_date, t2.amount AS t2_amount
  FROM MATCH (a1)-[t1:transfer]->(a2)-[t2:transfer]->(a1)
  WHERE t1.date < t2.date
""");

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
a1_account_no	t1_date	t1_amount	a2_account_no	t2_date	t2_amount
xxx-yyy-201	2018-10-05	200	xxx-yyy-202	2018-10-10	300

paragraphs.title: A to B to C to A
paragraphs.text:
%pgx
graph.queryPgql("""
  SELECT a1.account_no AS a1_account_no, t1.amount AS t1_amount
       , a2.account_no AS a2_account_no, t2.amount AS t2_amount
       , a3.account_no AS a3_account_no, t3.amount AS t3_amount
  MATCH (a1)-[t1:transfer]->(a2)-[t2:transfer]->(a3)-[t3:transfer]->(a1)
  WHERE t1.date < t2.date
  AND t2.date < t3.date
""");

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Influential Accounts

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4862919/63682708-b5707480-c822-11e9-8c59-0cae6ed22336.jpg)

paragraphs.title: Money Transfer Graph (graph2)
PageRank
paragraphs.text:
%pgx
analyst.pagerank(graph2);

%pgx
graph2.queryPgql("""
  SELECT a.account_no, a.pagerank
  MATCH (a)
  ORDER BY a.pagerank DESC
""");

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Community Detection

Let's find which subsets of accounts form communities. That is, there are more transfers among accounts in the same subset than there are between those and accounts in another subset. We'll use the built-in weekly / strongly connected components algorithm.

The first step is to create a subgraph that only has the accounts and the transfers among them. This is done by creating and applying an edge filter (for edges with the table "transfer') to the graph.

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4862919/63683125-c2419800-c823-11e9-8ca1-124a50398a5e.jpg)

msg.data:
Community Detection

Let’s find which subsets of accounts form communities. That is, there are more transfers among accounts in the same subset than there are between those and accounts in another subset. We’ll use the built-in weekly / strongly connected components algorithm.

The first step is to create a subgraph that only has the accounts and the transfers among them. This is done by creating and applying an edge filter (for edges with the table "transfer’) to the graph.

paragraphs.title: Weakly Connected Component
paragraphs.text:
%pgx
analyst.wcc(graph2)

%pgx
graph2.queryPgql("""
  SELECT a.wcc AS component_id, COUNT(*) AS count
  FROM MATCH (a)
  GROUP BY a.wcc
  ORDER BY a.wcc
""")

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Strongly Connected Component
paragraphs.text:
%pgx
analyst.sccKosaraju(graph2)

%pgx
graph2.queryPgql("""
  SELECT a.scc_kosaraju AS component_id, COUNT(a.account_no) AS count
  FROM MATCH (a)
  GROUP BY a.scc_kosaraju
  ORDER BY a.scc_kosaraju
""")

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Recommendation

Lastly let's use Personalized PageRank to find stores that John may purchase from given that people he is connected to have made purchases from those stores.

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4862919/63682622-8f4ad480-c822-11e9-9979-b8a1525240fe.jpg)

msg.data:
Recommendation

Lastly let’s use Personalized PageRank to find stores that John may purchase from given that people he is connected to have made purchases from those stores.

paragraphs.title: Product Purchase Graph (graph3)

paragraphs.text:
%md

Add reverse edges.

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4862919/63683184-eef5af80-c823-11e9-85be-495295d0c2a3.jpg)
![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4862919/63683190-f1f0a000-c823-11e9-8e3d-96152f4edf98.jpg)

paragraphs.title: Reverse Edges
paragraphs.text:
%pgx
cs = graph3.createChangeSet()
rs = graph3.queryPgql("SELECT a, x FROM MATCH (a)-[:purchased]->(x)")
i = 1
for (r in rs) {
    a = r.getVertex(1).getId()
    x = r.getVertex(2).getId()
    cs.addEdge(x, a).setLabel("purchased_by")
    i++
}
graph3 = cs.build()
graph3.queryPgql("""
  SELECT x.name, LABEL(r), a.account_no
  FROM MATCH (a)<-[r:purchased_by]-(x)
""")

paragraphs.title: Personalized PageRank
paragraphs.text:
%pgx
rs = graph3.queryPgql("SELECT a FROM MATCH (a) WHERE a.account_no = 'xxx-yyy-201'")
rs.next()
vertex = rs.getVertex(1)
analyst.personalizedPagerank(graph3, vertex)

paragraphs.title: Recommended Products
paragraphs.text:
%pgx
graph3.queryPgql("""
  SELECT ID(x), x.name, x.pagerank
  FROM MATCH (x)
  WHERE x.type = 'merchant'
    AND NOT EXISTS (
      SELECT *
      FROM MATCH (x)-[:purchased_by]->(a)
      WHERE a.account_no = 'xxx-yyy-201'
    )
  ORDER BY x.pagerank DESC
""")
